This report was prepared by A. Iffland, Project Economist.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the Country Programming Mission in 2001, the Government of Vanuatu and the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) agreed that ADB will provide grant funding for an advisory 
technical assistance project (TA) in 2003 to enhance the technical and vocational education and 
training  (TVET)  system.  The  agreement  was  confirmed  during  the  Country  Programming 
Mission in May 2002. 
 
2.  An ADB Fact-Finding Mission visited Vanuatu 26 September-18 October 2002.1 The 
Mission consulted widely with representatives from government agencies, formal and nonformal 
training providers, and aid agencies. The Mission visited Santo, Malekula, and Tanna islands 
and consulted with the provincial governments and education advisors, and training providers. 
The TA framework is in Appendix 1 and the summary initial social and poverty analysis is in 
Appendix 2. The Government reconfirmed its strong interest in and support for the TA, and 
highlighted its timeliness.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Over  the  past  4  years,  the  Government  has  focused  on  implementing  the 
Comprehensive  Reform  Program  (CRP).  The  CRP  has  emphasized  macroeconomic  and 
governance reforms and professionalization of the public sector. Much has been achieved in 
those areas, but the economic and political environment is still weak and unstable. Moreover, 
rural areas have not seen an improvement in the delivery of basic services, nor has economic 
development taken place there. The Prime Minister's annual policy statement of 3 June 2002 
reconfirmed this situation and stressed the importance of rural development as a key element in 
the Government's vision for Vanuatu.  
 
4.  Among 174 countries, Vanuatu ranks 124th  on the human development index. The 
United  Nations  considers  this  rank  as  medium  range;  nevertheless,  a  recently  conducted 
participatory poverty assessment3 indicates that the threat of poverty is increasing. Education 
standards are considered the poorest in the Pacific region. Adult literacy is only 64%, and infant 
mortality is high at 41 per 1,000 live births. 
 
5.  The estimated population growth rate is 3%, with the population under the age of 15 
years comprising 42.7% and  growth rate being 31.3% in the age group 15-35 years. Further, 
about 80% of the population live in rural areas, in geographically isolated small communities.  
Current trends indicate that the number of rural people could double over the next 23 years. 
Recent  reviews  of  community  priorities  undertaken  by  the  Rural  Economic  Development 
Initiatives (REDI) program as well as other community assessments and surveys of both formal 
and informal labor market demand all point to a common requirement of skills training to attain  
local development priorities and the income-generating aspirations of the youth and rural people 
in  general.  This  demographic  and  socioeconomic  backdrop  makes  skills  development 
imperative and explains the priority given to providing skills in a variety of government initiatives. 
The initiatives range from the CRP to the more recent move to reassign the responsibilities of 
the previous Ministry of Youth and Sport, which is now named the Ministry of Training and 
Youth Development (MTYD).

6.  In 2000, a review of TVET provided details of Vanuatu's system. The review included an 
assessment  of  the  demand  and  supply  of  nonformal  vocational  skills  training  and  the 
development of alternative strategies to enhance delivery.4  Assessments of the training needs 
of a sample of 22 rural communities from all six provinces revealed the lack of a wide range of 
basic vocational skills, which are considered essential to improve the livelihood of the rural 
communities and generate supplementary cash income for families. An informal survey, which 
was part of the TA (footnote 4), demonstrated the growing importance of this sector and the 
type of business activities it comprises. The training levels of proprietors were generally low and 
their  perceived  training  needs  ranged  from  technical  skills  upgrading  to  small  business 
management. On the supply side, skills development is currently undertaken by a variety of 
nonformal training providers, ranging from community-based rural training centers (RTCs) and 
inputs  from  church-led  groups,  women  and  youth  institutions,  and  other  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), mostly operating in the rural areas. RTCs are the only major training 
venue in most parts of rural Vanuatu. However, the number of operational but ill-equipped RTCs 
has declined from 44 in 1999 to under 30 in 2002 as they continue to face serious financial 
problems. Most RTC managers quote the inability of students to pay course fees as the main 
reason. The very basic training offered by women and church groups is organized on an ad hoc 
basis, subject to the availability of grant funding and the financial capacity of the participants. 
The Government does not provide funding for nonformal training, but faces increased pressure 
to address the causes of the lack of skills training in rural areas. Formal, generally government-
funded, skills training is limited to two church-led technical schools and the Vanuatu Institute of 
Technology (VIT). The latter offers officially recognized certificate and diploma courses. To date 
there have been no formal linkages between the formal and nonformal training programs and 
only limited contact in terms of information exchange, technical guidance, or assistance. Both 
the review and the subsequent participatory workshop in 2001, which was attended by over 70 
representatives from relevant national and provincial institutions, showed that the  TVET must 
be seen as part of a continuum of training opportunities, no matter where or how it was 
delivered, and that such training should be targeted at providing a range of income-generating 
skills appropriate to local needs. The results of the workshop were taken up by the Vanuatu 
National Training Council (VNTC) and (i) are reflected in the Bill for VIT, (ii) formed the starting 
point for the Education for All (EFA) task force and are integrated into Vanuatu's National Action 
Plan for EFA, and (iii) are the key elements of the policy and budget directives for MTYD.   
 
7.  The requirement of sustainable resources–both financial and material–to support and 
maintain training initiatives at all levels, particularly in rural areas, was also stressed as a 
priority. These concerns were given further impetus by a subsequent consultation process in 
August 2002 at which over 80 stakeholders expressed their support for the policy directions 
prepared  for  the  new  MTYD  and  proposed  that  the  Government  should  adopt  the  
recommendation of UNESCO that access to TVET should be seen as a right as described in 
Article 26 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. 
 
8.  To  address  these  issues  the  Government  has  already  enacted  legislation  that  has 
established the VNTC, with representation from concerned government ministries, the private 
sector, and formal and nonformal training providers. VNTC has been made responsible for 
planning, coordinating, and assisting formal and nonformal TVET at both national and provincial 
levels.  A  VNTC  secretariat  will  be  appointed  shortly  through  regular  official  budgetary 
allocations to facilitate these activities.  Further legislation has been prepared to broaden the

3 
scope of VIT, giving it a wider responsibility that will enable it to provide sustainable technical 
and advisory support to the provinces and other nonformal training providers in areas such as 
trainer training and curriculum development. To accomplish this wider scope, existing training 
facilities, which can range from secondary and technical schools to RTCs, will be designated as 
VIT provincial campuses.5 The aim is to have one in each of the six provinces. These training 
facilities will provide new bridging courses designed to provide linkages between formal and 
nonformal programs. Trained staff will provide a genuine provincially based TVET resource in 
terms of advice, guidance and materials available to all local training providers. Most important, 
the new provincial campuses will introduce new modular training courses that can be used by all 
local training providers and which can build up to a Vanuatu Community Certificate and a 
Vanuatu Foundation Certificate offering new options in literacy, numeracy, self-reliance and self-
subsistence, and personal and community development. Although each module will be a stand-
alone  unit  capable  of  enhancing  an  individual’s  capacity  to  improve  his  or  her  livelihood, 
assembled together over time they can open up a pathway to a formally recognized career 
structure.  
 
9.  To support  these initiatives and the institutions tasked with their implementation, there is 
a need to develop new policies and delivery modalities.  Formal education already has its 
master plan. The TVET sector also needs a master plan to guide national development and to 
assist each province to set its own training priorities based on local needs already identified by 
REDI programs.  Proposals for provincial campuses need to be elaborated, their implications 
identified, and their potential benefits assessed as part of the bridges that should be built 
between disadvantaged youth and rural communities and the opportunities presented by the 
formal labor market. To avoid the disappointment caused by failed expectations of potential 
beneficiaries, these new developments need to be supported by sustainable funding resources. 
Trials are therefore needed to demonstrate how such sustainability of funding could be built into 
future developments of the TVET system in Vanuatu.        
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The  TA  will  assist  the  Government  to  establish  and  operationalize  a  national  and 
provincial TVET framework that will facilitate continuous life-long learning. The framework will 
lay the foundation for a systematic and sustainable approach to provide young people and 
adults with equitable access to appropriate learning and life skills as stipulated in Vanuatu's 
national action plan for EFA–the overall goal the TA aims to contribute to.  The TA will have the 
following outputs: (i) a national TVET master plan; (ii) provincial TVET implementation plans, 
including  proposals  for  six  provincial  campuses;  (iii)  an  organizational  structure  and 
implementation arrangements for a sustainable TVET training fund; and (iv) the delivery of 
nonformal, income-oriented skills training using the pilot TVET training fund mechanism.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TVET master plan and the associated provincial TVET implementation plans will be 
prepared by key stakeholders with the support of a TVET policy advisor through a series of 
provincial and national workshops and conferences. Senior government officials concerned with 
                                                 
5 No new infrastructure will be required. Existing training facilities will be strengthened mainly through capacity 
building for human resources, e.g., upgrading teachers, training headmasters/managers, to fulfill the role of a 
provincial campus. These facilities will be the link between the formal and the nonformal TVET system.

4  
the development of TVET and nongovernment stakeholders involved in delivering TVET will 
examine various TVET models in the Asia Pacific region. A guided study tour will facilitate this 
process. The experiences and insights gained will be presented at the first of a series of 
national conferences. The preparation of the provincial action plans will be facilitated by VNTC, 
VIT,  and  MTYD  through  a  series  of  provincial  stakeholder  workshops.  The  costing  of  the 
implementation  of  the  provincial  implementation  plans,  and  the  selection  of  host  training 
institutions for the VIT provincial campuses form an integrated part of this participatory process. 
The national conferences will focus (i) on the overall TVET master plan and the linkages with 
the provincial implementation plans complementing REDI, and (ii) the organizational structure 
and  implementation  arrangements  for  the  training  fund.  Key  provincial  stakeholders  will 
participate in these conferences.  
 
12.  The development of the organizational structure and implementation arrangements for a 
sustainable TVET training fund will be facilitated by an advisor on training fund operations. The 
organizational  structure  at  national  and  provincial  levels,  an  operational  manual,  and  the 
constitution of the training fund will be developed with support from VNTC and finalized at a 
national stakeholder workshop (para. 11). This funding mechanism will be pilot-tested during the 
second year of TA implementation with the start of the skills training (para. 13). The outreach 
and impact of training by nonformal training providers–the direct beneficiaries of the training 
fund–will be assessed. This will provide the basis for a  Government decision on whether to 
introduce a larger training fund, which will use the accrued interest on the capital only, and by 
doing so will have an unlimited operation period.6  
 
13.  The delivery of nonformal, income-oriented skills training using the pilot TVET training 
fund mechanism will be achieved through (i) a series of technical training-of-trainer programs in 
the  provinces,  designed  to  upgrade  the  technical  and  teaching  capacity  of  local  training 
providers; (ii) a 1-month training7 program for one VNTC executive staff in applying costing, 
selecting,  and  monitoring  short-term  income-oriented  skills  training;  (iii)  a  national  training 
program  on  the  preparation  and  screening  of  training  proposals;  and  (iv)  the  provision  of 
$50,000 to fund, monitor, and evaluate short-term income-generating skills training. The TA will 
fund up to 70% of the total training costs.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
14.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $325,000 equivalent, of which $149,000 is the foreign 
exchange  cost  and  $176,000  equivalent  is  the  local  currency  cost.  The  Government  has 
requested ADB to finance $250,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$101,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB's TA funding program. The Government will provide counterpart staff, transport, and office, 
workshop, and communication facilities amounting to $60,000 equivalent in local currency, and 
the training providers8 will contribute $15,000 equivalent in kind for skills training, amounting 
together to 30% of the total project cost. The TA will finance (i) international consulting services; 
(ii) one study tour for senior government officials and key TVET stakeholders; (iii) a series of 
provincial workshops and national conferences; (iv) 1 month of training for a VNTC executive

officer in the operational procedures of the training fund; (v) a series of provincial training-the- 
trainer workshops; and (vi) up to 200 skills training courses for school dropouts, unemployed 
youth and women, particularly those in rural areas. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The Department of Economic and Social Development (DESD) will be the Executing 
Agency of the TA. MTYD will be the Implementing Agency and will, in cooperation with VNTC 
and VIT, provide counterpart staff, office space, and transport and communication facilities. The 
team of consultants will work under the overall guidance of the director general of education, 
training and youth development.9 The executive secretary of VNTC and the principal of VIT will 
work on a day-to-day basis with the team of international consultants.  
 
16.  The two international consultants will have specialization in (i) TVET policy, and  (ii) 
training fund operations. The consultants’ terms of reference are in Appendix 4. The TA will be 
implemented over a period of about 24 months (February 2003-January 2005). The assignment 
of the consultant for TVET policy (3 person-months) will be carried out in two phases: at the 
beginning and at mid-point of the implementation period. During phase 1, the consultants will 
assist MTYD in preparing the first draft of the TVET master plan and guide the study tour for 
senior government officials. Phase 2 will focus on the synthesis of the provincial implementation 
plans and the TVET master plan and the presentation of the final draft for approval by the 
Vanuatu Council of Ministers.  The TVET policy consultant will submit (i) an interim progress 
report upon completion of  phase 1 of the TA, and (ii) a draft final report in accordance with the 
terms of reference 2 weeks after the completion of  phase 2 of the TA. The international 
consultant for training fund operations (1 person-month) will advise the Government on the 
organizational structure and operational procedures of the training fund and will prepare a draft 
final report within 2 weeks after completion of the assignment. The expected TA completion 
date is January 2005. The individual consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Vanuatu for the Policy Framework and Capacity Building for Technical and 
Vocational Education and Training, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 4  11 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR INTERNATIONAL CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Technical  and  Vocational  Education  and  Training  Policy  Specialist  (3  person-
months) 
1.  The  specialist  in  formal/nonformal  technical  and  vocational  education  and  training 
(TVET) policy will assist the Ministry of Training and Youth Development (MTYD) to design a 
national TVET master plan and provide further assistance to all six provinces to give specific 
provincial dimensions to the overall TVET master plan.  Working in conjunction with the Vanuatu 
National Training Council (VNTC), the consultant will assist the VNTC and its secretariat to 
facilitate the delivery of relevant aspects of the TVET master plan and to begin training all 
relevant training providers with respect to their potential roles and responsibilities.  In addition, 
the specialist assess the requirements for a more coordinated and equitable system of TVET 
delivery at provincial levels, including proposals for provincial campuses of Vanuatu Institute of 
Technology (VIT), and to review their potential benefits as part of a new TVET delivery system 
offering  relevant  curriculum  and  certification  designed  to  match  local  training  needs.    The 
consultant will also participate in an overview of a trial designed to test the provision of local 
sustainable funding mechanisms. 
 
2.  In particular, the consultant will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  Conduct initial briefings and data gathering to identify the parameters of the 
TVET master plan. 
(ii)  Accompany representatives of MTYD, VNTC, and VIT on visits to the provinces 
to  present,  discuss  and  assess  with  local  representatives  the  provincial 
application of TVET policies. 
(iii)  Prepare  and  participate  in  national  and  provincial  workshops  leading  to  the 
formulation and presentation of a TVET master plan. 
(iv)  Train counterparts from MTYD, VNTC, VIT, and other concerned formal and non-
formal institutions in designing and implementing  TVET policies. 
(v)  Facilitate the planning and execution of a study visit on relevant aspects of TVET 
policy and their implementation in selected countries in the Asia and Pacific 
region and beyond. 
(vi)  Assist in the preparing and presenting of both a draft and final version of the 
TVET master plan. 
(vii)  Cooperate with MTYD, VNTC, VIT, and provincial officials in identifying and 
assessing potential benefits arising from a devolved system for TVET delivery. 
(viii)  Assist  with  identifying  potential  sites,  design  and  costings  for  the  proposed 
provincial campuses. 
(ix)  Provide  inputs  to  the  design,  implementation,  and  review  of  a  trial  for  a 
sustainable funding mechanism for delivering local training initiatives. 
(x)  Prepare (a) an interim progress report upon completion of phase 1 of the TA, and 
(ii) a draft final report in accordance with the terms of reference 2 weeks after the 
completion of phase 2 of the TA, including recommendations for any further 
investment required to support TVET at both national and provincial levels. 
 
3.  The consultant will have (i) a degree in some aspect of rural development combined with 
a postgraduate qualification in TVET; (ii) at least 10 years experience in  design/implementation 
of  TVET  systems,  with  particular  reference  to  rural  applications;  (iii)  experience  with

B.  Training Fund Specialist (1 person-month)  
4.  The  specialist  will  provide  advisory  services  to  finalize  the  design  and  overall 
implementation arrangements for a sustainable financing mechanism. These responsibilities will 
be carried out in close collaboration with MTYD, the members and executive secretary of the 
VNTC, senior staff of relevant government and nongovernment training providers, private sector 
representatives, and other relevant Government officials. 
 
5.  In particular, the consultant will undertake the following activities:  
(i)  Provide specialist inputs during the national TVET master plan workshops to 
develop  and  finalize  a  proposal  for  establishing  a  sustainable  financing 
mechanism to support nonformal, income-oriented short courses for wage and 
self-employment. 
(ii)  Discuss and finalize the concept for a sustainable financing mechanism with the 
Ministry of Finance, Department of Economic and Social Development (DESD), 
MTYD, and selected government and nongovernment training providers. 
(iii)  Assist VNTC in finalizing a proposed organizational structure for a sustainable 
financing mechanism at national and provincial levels. 
(iv)  Establish a selection mechanism for the members of the board at national and 
provincial levels with corresponding functional terms of reference for the national 
board, provincial committees, and national and provincial secretariats. 
(v)  Draft appropriate guidelines and selection criteria for training providers to access 
a sustainable financing mechanism. 
(vi)  Provide  guidance  to  selected  provincial  staff  developing  comprehensive 
guidelines  and  procedures  on  submitting  training  proposals,  appraising  and 
awarding cofinancing support, and developing suitable formats for submission 
and costing of short courses. 
(vii)  Provide a draft proposal for a management information system–on national and 
provincial  levels–to  assist  in  transparent  and  efficient  processing  of  training 
proposals on national and provincial levels. 
(viii)  Ensure that all draft legal documents are prepared to ensure that registration of 
the sustainable financing mechanism can be effected upon receipt of financial 
contributions. 
(ix)  Evaluate  the  financial  and  economic  viability  of  the  sustainable  financing 
mechanism, including the proposal for financing options based on cash flow 
projections. 
(x)  Prepare a draft final report within 2 weeks after completion of the assignment. 
 
6.  The  consultant  will  have  (i)  extensive  experience  in  designing  and  implementing 
sustainable  funding  mechanisms,  (ii)  5  years  experience  in  rural  development,  and  (iii) 
experience with funding mechanisms in the Pacific.
